64.80.text:

86.52.text:

460.03.text:
Thirteen and a half years

462.60.text:
dangerous world. And, in
2015, we must recognize

467.80.text:
that we have evolved to
a new phase in the global

471.27.text:
terrorist threat. Today
the terrorist threat is

474.21.text:
more decentralized, more
diffuse, and more complex.

478.34.text:
We are concerned about the
so-called foreign fighter

481.65.text:
who leaves his home
country, travels to

483.95.text:
another country to take up
the fight there, links up

486.99.text:
with terrorist extremists,
and may return home -

490.12.text:
whether it's this country
or one of our allies --

493.99.text:
with a terrorist extremist
purpose. We are concerned

500.93.text:
and skilled use of the
internet to publicly

503.80.text:
recruit individuals to
conduct attacks within

506.91.text:
their own homelands. AQAP
no longer builds bombs in

511.44.text:
secret; it has now
publicized its instruction

514.38.text:
manual, and has called for
people to use it. We are

520.49.text:
lurking in our midst --
the so-called "lone wolf"

523.76.text:
-- who may become
inspired by this extremist

526.09.text:
propaganda on the

528.90.text:

532.73.text:

First, as everyone knows,

536.24.text:
we are taking the fight
to these groups, in places

538.94.text:
like Iraq and Syria. Our
intelligence community

542.21.text:
continues to detect
terrorist plots at their

551.05.text:
plots in the homeland.

554.69.text:

the public calls by

612.31.text:

690.46.text:

713.51.text:

883.32.text:
facts. In June 2013,

your best guess --

911.41.text:
In the year 2000,
apprehensions on the

913.41.text:

916.15.text:

922.89.text:
southern border have

Apprehensions are in fact

945.94.text:

952.42.text:
the largest deployment

954.95.text:

90-year history. This

960.63.text:

969.90.text:
Without a doubt, we had

972.20.text:
with the unprecedented

975.24.text:

986.29.text:

Beginning in mid-June the

991.72.text:

sharply, and are now at

1002.47.text:

1004.70.text:

and a smart strategy to

get there. Much of illegal

1012.14.text:

1030.56.text:

1044.64.text:

public awareness messaging

in other areas to promote

1259.99.text:
responsible for assisting

1360.36.text:
and financial crimes.
However, recent events

1363.40.text:
have highlighted the need
for change. In October I

1366.90.text:
appointed an independent
panel to take a hard look

1369.63.text:
at the Secret Service.
In December the panel

1372.11.text:
reported its findings
back to me. Those

1375.11.text:
recommendations were
astute, thorough and fair.

1378.25.text:
A number of security
enhancements have already

1381.85.text:
been made and implemented
by Acting Director Clancy,

1385.08.text:
but the Secret Service
must also commit to longer

1387.89.text:
term and more systemic
change. For my part, I am

1391.99.text:
committed to sustained and
encouraged oversight of

1394.73.text:
the Secret Service, to
ensure that it has what it

1397.63.text:
needs to get the job done.
Last year our Federal Law

1406.30.text:
officers and agents from
federal, state, local,

1410.21.text:
tribal and international
law enforcement. We are

1413.28.text:
ensuring that the Coast
Guard has what it needs to

1417.98.text:
get its job done. These
are exciting times for the

1421.12.text:
Coast Guard, as it is
replacing its aging fleet

1424.06.text:
with new vessels. Four new
National Security Cutters

1426.89.text:
are in service and a fifth
will be commissioned this

1429.93.text:
summer. Twelve new Fast
Response Cutters have been

1433.10.text:
delivered and are making
a difference every day in

1435.93.text:
south Florida, and we
are more than halfway to

1438.50.text:
completing the replacement
of our fleet of aged

1441.31.text:
patrol boats. Meanwhile,
the Coast Guard is in the

1444.08.text:
design phase of a new
mid-size Offshore Patrol

1447.61.text:
Cutter. I am committed to
ensuring this project is

1450.58.text:
affordable before going
forward with the selection

1453.95.text:
of a general contractor
and production. FEMA has

1461.39.text:
agency in the country and
has earned the confidence

1464.80.text:
of federal, state and
local leaders throughout.

1468.20.text:
In the year I've been in
office, I have personally

1470.20.text:
had the opportunity to
observe this at disaster

1472.97.text:
recovery sites. Finally,
DHS cannot pursue all

1479.44.text:
these important missions
alone. I cannot print

1483.15.text:
money. I cannot
appropriate money. We need

1486.82.text:
a continued partnership
with Congress. We need a

1495.26.text:
At present DHS is
operating on a continuing

1498.70.text:
resolution which expires
on February 27. As long as

1503.20.text:
we are on a CR, we are
restricted to last year's

1506.07.text:
spending levels, and
cannot engage in any new

1508.94.text:
spending and activities.
This means we cannot pay

1513.28.text:
for the added border
security that I talked

1515.65.text:
about. This means we
cannot invest in the

1518.38.text:
things the independent
panel recommended to

1521.19.text:
improve the Secret
Service; we cannot hire

1523.76.text:
new Secret Service
agents for the coming

1525.86.text:
presidential election
cycle. This means we

1528.39.text:
cannot fund new
non-disaster grants for

1531.54.text:
state and local
governments that mayors,

1535.44.text:
police chiefs, fire
chiefs, and governors

1538.07.text:
depend on. Our ability to
fund aviation security,

1543.04.text:
maritime security, port
security and homeland

1545.74.text:
security is severely
constrained as long as we

1549.01.text:
are on a CR. As
originally introduced by

1552.18.text:
the House Appropriations
Committee, the FY 2015

1556.02.text:
appropriations bill for
the Department of Homeland

1558.36.text:
Security was a good bill.
It appropriated $39.7

1562.13.text:
billion for the Department
and funded many of the

1564.63.text:
things we need. On the
House floor the bill was

1569.63.text:
language to defund all our
executive actions to fix

1573.94.text:
the immigration system.
The President has vowed to

1576.88.text:
veto any bill that
includes such language.

1581.81.text:
The clock to February
27 is ticking. In these

1585.02.text:
times, the homeland
security budget of this

1588.29.text:
government should not be a
political football. I urge

1592.72.text:
Congress to pass an
appropriations bill for

1594.89.text:
DHS, free and clear
of politically-charged

1599.23.text:
amendments. I will end
with the very last two

1604.87.text:
words I ended last year's
speech with. Last year, I

1609.67.text:
said that, in the name
of homeland security, we

1613.98.text:
should not sacrifice our
values as a Nation of

1617.28.text:
people who cherish privacy
and freedom, celebrate

1620.49.text:
diversity, and are not
afraid. Fear is corrosive.

1626.52.text:
In the final analysis,
courage and resolve in the

1630.33.text:
face of challenge are the
greatest strengths of any

1633.17.text:
nation. Terrorism cannot
advance if we refuse to be

1637.34.text:
terrorized. Whether in
response to a terrorist

1640.47.text:
threat, a natural
disaster, a deadly virus,

1644.68.text:
or in the pursuit of
a more perfect union,

1647.45.text:
courage and resolve
will always prevail.
